questions.question_text: A financial consulting firm recently recovered from some damaging incidents that were associated with malware installed via rootkit. Post-incident analysis is ongoing, and the incident responders and systems administrators are working to determine a strategy to reduce the risk of recurrence. The firm's systems are running modern operating systems and feature UEFI and TPMs. Which of the following technical options would provide the MOST preventive value?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
There is no doubt. 
Best preventative measure from root kits is 

B. Configure and use measured boot

Selected Answer: B
B. Configure and use measured boot

A Measured Boot helps better protect your machine from rootkits and other malware. Measured Boot will check each start up component including the firmware all the way to the boot drivers and it will store this information in what is called a Trusted Platform Module (TPM).

Selected Answer: D
I'm almost leaning towards the given answer. The question says the systems are modern and have TPMs. Based on what Ive read on TPMs, (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/information-protection/tpm/trusted-platform-module-overview) they sort of already have a function of ensuring proper boot code. I feel like it may be a trick question. Which would provide the MOST preventative value, which would be D because the antivirus would catch more than just measured boot would. I'm torn between answering the question and answering the comptia question.
Root kit is the key word, measured boot is made partially to protect against root kits

Measured Boot is a new feature of Windows 8 that was created to help better protect your machine from rootkits and other malware. Measured Boot will check each start up component including the firmware all the way to the boot drivers and it will store this information in what is called a Trusted Platform Module (TPM).

B
Measured boot would be the way to monitor for root kits in the future.
"Measured Boot doesn’t make an implicit value judgement as to good or bad, and it doesn’t stop the platform from running, so Measured Boot can be much more liberal about what it checks."
https://community.juniper.net/answers/blogs/elevate-member/2020/12/22/whats-the-difference-between-secure-boot-and-measured-boot
B.. should be the answer.
ANSR IS B
B. Configure and use measured boot

choices.D: Update the antivirus software and definitions

questions.question_text: Which of the following are the MOST likely vectors for the unauthorized or unintentional inclusion of vulnerable code in a software company's final software releases? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
On second thought, I think would go with:
A. Unsecure protocols
D. Included third-party libraries
The question is asking what *practices* could cause the unintentional inclusion of insecure source code from the developers.

Maybe: D. Included third-party libraries?
Read this question very carefully. They seem to asking: "what caused the software development team to unintentionally include vulnerable code?" They are not asking: "what are common software vulnerabilities?" They are asking about poor practices in the development process. When you understand the question, it seems that answers A and C make no sense. 
Of all the answers the only two that make any sense are: "Included third-party libraries" because the developers don't know if those libraries are secure. And: "Vendors/supply chain" - by selecting bad vendors, the

questions.question_text: A security manager needed to protect a high-security data center, so the manager installed a mantrap that can detect an employee's heartbeat, weight, and badge. Which of the following did the security manager implement?

discussion.content:
Maybe: A. A physical control? 
A mantrap is being used to control *physical* access to the data center.
Why are there so many wrong answers on this website? It really gets confusing.
Going with A on this one

It's A
Compensating controls have nothing to do with this question https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/comptia-security-certification/9781789348019/164c4766-4274-4bd5-accc-bbee92d326b5.xhtml

questions.question_text:
A security administrator adding a NAC requirement for all VPN users to ensure the connecting devices are compliant with company policy. Which of the following

items provides the HIGHEST
assurance to meet this requirement?

discussion.content: This is option A! Permanent Agent should be install on NAC. A single installation that travels with the computer. Once the software is installed, the user never has to interact with it again. Offers deep inspection of the host.

Selected Answer: A
"A permanent agent (sometimes called a persistent NAC agent) is installed on the client and stays on the client. NAC uses the agent when the client attempts to log on remotely. This is the most common implementation for corporate-owned devices, and for approved laptops and PCs that employees use to connect remotely."

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/security-nac-darril-gibson/
why PKI?

questions.question_text: Ann, a security manager, is reviewing a threat feed that provides information about attacks that allow a malicious user to gain access to private contact lists. Ann receives a notification that the vulnerability can be exploited within her environment. Given this information, Ann can anticipate an increase in:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - Vishing - voice equivalent of phishing
Going with B on this one
is B you can get access to contact list inside a SQL DB using SQL injections attacks.

comments.content: I like this explanation. Agree with vishing.
Don’t overthink it. The contacts are exposed. We can expect some robo calls. Vishing it is.

Vishing is different from phishing as vishing involves calling to someone to perform social engineering.

https://www.kaspersky.com/resource-center/definitions/vishing

discussion.content:
A. Vishing attacks
Access to the email contact list allows the attacker to send phishing emails from seemingly known sources.
